But rather than retreat, South Australia leaned in, investing in big batteries, so-called synchronous compressors (which mimic the stabilising â€œinertiaâ€ of fossil fuel-powered turbines), and even more wind and solar. Last year, the state sourced 75% of its electricity from renewables and hasnâ€™t had another blackout since. However, Spain and Portugal are mostly cut off, with just a weak link to France through the Pyrenees mountains. That makes them more vulnerable during outages.Â  Although the exact cause of the blackout is still under investigation, the disruption â€” which saw Spainâ€™s grid lose 15GW of energy in just five seconds â€” has raised serious doubts about the regionâ€™s energy infrastructure. These include rooftop panels, home batteries, and local wind farms, which generate electricity closer to where itâ€™s used.Â  â€œCloser to our homes and offices, at the edge of the grid, we need to deploy flexible capacity, and we need smarter grids and greater transparency,â€ he told TNW. Overall, what emerges is a complex picture of rapid progress outpacing preparation. The blackout wasnâ€™t a failure of renewables â€” it was a failure to keep up with them. If Europe wants a cleaner future, its grids need to catch up fast.Â  â€œInvesting in net-zero infrastructure is a core part of the solution, not the problem,â€ said Glover.
